One of the major purposes of "phishing" is to mine data that can be sold on the "dark web" to other scammers. The ultimate goal is to finally obtain things like hard working people's social security numbers, credit/debit card numbers, and bank account routing numbers and can be used to enrich the criminal class who are often located on the other side of our planet. As a general rule, NEVER provide any of this information to anybody who "cold calls" you on the phone, sends you emails with links that do not take you exactly to where they should, or claims to be from the IRS, FBI, or the police. If in doubt, see if you can independently verify the origin of such requests. I you can not, then it's a sure sign that you are being set up for a scam that could cost you thousands of dollars that you will never see again.

These are simple phishing pages, there are actual github repositories which contain phishing pages looking exactly like the google login pages (hey, not that hard, just copy the plane source code which is available to read from every website in nearly every browser). This phishing page stores your password in a simple .txt file on the server of the attacker, and then relays you to a google error page (mostly just a 404 - not found page withing the google.com domain, or an actual login page from google)

What happens after you put your details in the fake website, normally using http (not https, so it's plain text, easier to read than uncrypting) your data is stored into a database, including IP, Geolocalitation, ISP, Time and the attacker can sum up more details and give them to you, like tracking cookies.

If an email asks you to check something, or go to a link, go to the original website. What happens is that your Youtube account will be fine.  Phishing sites like these don't care about your social media accounts or anything like that.  What they will do is try using your password **ON OTHER WEBSITES** !!!!!!!!!

Because if people are noobish enough to click a fake link and enter their username and password on the fake site, then the hackers assume those same people are noobish enough to use the same email address and password on other webpages!!!!!

This is why so many people get hacked!  Most people use the same password on everything!  Their Ebay account, their paypal account, their Xbox Live or PSN account, their bestbuy account, THEIR BANKING ACCOUNT!  Ugh... the list goes on.

This is why you should NEVER EVER use the same password on any webpages!   Or at least, the very least, never use the same password as a social media site and another page that contains your credit card.

(edit) oh and btw, make sure your passwords from one site to another isn't similar to one another.  Just because your password is "bacon123" on youtube and your password for paypal is "bacon321" doesn't mean you're safe!  The hackers will try several password combinations to find out your real password.

I never thought that I would see a PSA on in a youtube video.

Given that a google account does not typically carry financial information it will most likely not be all that devastating, you could expect to see unsolicited ads and the like.  However, people may not realize the overwhelming power of google.  For instance, consider this app: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/chrome-remote-desktop/gbchcmhmhahfdphkhkmpfmihenigjmpp?utm_source=chrome-ntp-icon
If a person had the unlucky combination of falling for this and having that app, anything and everything on their computer could potentially be controlled or discovered by another, such as saved passwords for sites like amazon, or your bank.
For this reason I will make my own PSA:
1 - DO NOT EVER let your browser save your bank's login credentials, just remember them
2 - When ordering things online always go into your account settings for the site you just ordered from and delete your credit/debit card, amazon saves this automatically and it will need to be deleted every time, for steam and newegg it is only necessary to uncheck a checkbox during the payment process, I can't say for sure for any other sites.
3 - If you are in doubt, you don't know what you are doing well enough to buy online.  Do not use the internet for financial things unless you are without a shadow of a doubt that you know what you are doing.
4 - Proxy servers are a mixed blessing, they may help hide you from others, but sometimes the severs giving you proxy are owned by the people you should be hiding from.

5 - The safest way to buy online is by using a pre-paid credit card, the kind that you load cash onto in walmart or other stores, you can't possibly have any more money stolen from it than the amount the you have loaded onto it (yes you can find them in a re-loadable version, look for "green-dot" cards).

A bit of misunderstanding about the real threat of these e-mails. Phishing has been around since the dawn of the time people realized "Hey I can link to ANYTHING!". It is not a complex hacking scheme, it doesnt require knowledge of internet protocols or an understanding of how server requests work (ala Heartbleed, though that in itself was embarassing and didnt require much knowledge either). Its the simpler of the hacks. Mostly done as a minor operation by a group with malicious intent or down by "script kiddies" as they are commonly referred to.

The beauty is that it relies on one of the best methods, Social Engineering. They target the uninformed and try as much as possible to appear like a true support team. The truth is you cant stop it either, you can only inform your users to minimize the risks. There is no way to get a IP Address/Website blocked in a reasonable time period. And likely the people who can do that dont want to deal with such a small attack when their are tons of other malicious attacks going on. Just be informed... DONT CLICK LINKS IN EMAILS WITHOUT BEING SURE AS TO WHERE IT LINKS! Simple as that. They can obscure the real link location but the Web page HAS to have the information, you just need to find it.

What can you do to help prevent this?
One thing would be to set up 2-step verification on your Google Account.  This way if you accidentally gave someone you're password, they still can't get in without having your cellphone too.  And, don't use the same password on other sites.

There is no perfect solution, but 2-step is your best bet here (other then being careful where you type your info into).  But, if you where to have a brain fart and type your password into this site, 2-step verification would not only stop them from getting in, but you'll get a text message when they try to login.  This will allow you to change your password.  Without 2-step verification, once you type your info in, they have access to your account and you won't even know they were logged in.

If you have access to someone's email account, its very easy to bypass third party site's two factor authentication. For example Coinbase or Blockchain.info. Hackers who get access to people's email addresses that have bitcoins can very easily take those bitcoins.

Well, what I always recommend is: When you get an email of any kind like this from any company, if they ask you to eighter verify your account, check up on weird activity on your account, etc, what you always should do is to manually go to their site and log in from there, because if the email is legit, you can find the information they want to give you at their site anyhow

Basically; instead of clicking email links, go there manually, if it can be sent in email link, it can be manually found on their site as well.

The fake site seems to be made in a rush as the ip of the "puppet" (wich is the victim machine used to create a website without domain [also presuming the creator of the site is smart enough to use a "puppet" machine]) machine shows in the link.

The "best" phishing I've seen is on ebay - updates were made to listings (the seller claimed it was done without his knowledge) that simply pulled in some external javascript, the result of which was getting redirected to a fake ebay login page. 

So looking at the wrong listing would seem to get ebay to ask you to login again - as websites do this occasionally  it probably won't ring alarm bells with most people.  I only realised because firefox hadn't saved my password, obviously if I'd looked closer the login URL was bogus. 

This is far more subtle than the usual phishing emails - where the first line of defence would normally be to go to the website in question and see if the email was legit.  How do you do that if the website can be compromised?

Worrying as this attack seemed, it took a lot of time to get ebay to acknowledge it and they really didn't seem that interested.  The seller seemed surprisingly blasé about the whole thing - he was more concerned about having to delete a listing that had been around for ages (seems having a large "X items sold" counter is a good thing for him).  Though at least ebay and the seller responded, which is more than the UK police did :)

The most "useful" account for a hacker to gain access to is your email account. Once in your email, the hacker will scan your emails for accounts you hold, poorly designed password reset & account info emails that contain your password in plain text (which is then tested against the emails they found indicating which websites you have an account on), and most critical - if they cannot access one of your accounts, they just click "Forgot my password", which a password reset link is sent to, you guessed it, your email account that they now have access to, thanks to you willingly handing over your password via the phishing attack.

I know how this phshing scam works:

The website it redirects to is an exact copy of the website it would otherwise legitimately go to, exept the link is of a custom-made website that only shows an extremely convincing logging request page for a target website account.

So, when submited a loggin request on this fake site, it generates a message with your credentials and sends it to the owner's e-mail, allowing him to store it. He can then do what ever he wants with the account he stole.

And this doesn't end here...after saving your account's credentials, this fake site AUTOMATICALLY REDIRECTS YOU TO THE REAL LOGGIN WEBSITE AND SUBMITS A LOGGING REQUEST WITH THE INFORMTION YOU JUST TYPED IN, meaning if you didn't catch the FAKE website in the first place, you probably wont notice anything odd once you're on your account and  the phiser alredy has your credentials.

If the logging fails, it will show the exact same error as it would on the real website and keeps asking for you to submit.

The best way to check if you are on the real website and not some phishing duplicate, if you don't have any knowledge about urls and links, is to check the leftmost part of the url in the address bar of your browser. That part will be green when the site has a valid certificate of authenticity, which is checked by your browser (I know for sure that Chrome, Firefox and Opera do this). A fake website will never have such a certificate.

Okay guys, Like this so everyone can see and be safe. Follow these tips and you should be fine

1) Check the URL, Make sure it is legit.
2) If it's a huge company like Google, Youtube, Paypal, Amazon; The login will have https://(SOMETHING) instead of http://(SOMETHING) , look for that S
3) Understand It's easy to fully replicate websites. Anything can be copied from a website including the Logo and functions.
4)BEST TIP OF ALL:
To make sure it is a legit website, first put in a fake password. If it appears that you are logged in with the fake password, then it IS a phishing website.
5) Just because the domain looks similar to the actual domain, try to use the other steps also.

Thank you and please let the world know these tips to stay safe!

What happens is this: you are on the fake YouTube login. Now, the IP is most likely XAMPP hosted, or personally hosted. So, the phisher basically copied the HTML, and implemented his own PHP code. This PHP code is unreadable to the public, so it sends the credentials to the guy's email. This is you accidentally using the POST method, which sends your credentials. From there, the guy logs into your account with the credentials on the real YouTube, and screws up your account.

These emails are not sent to you as such, they are sent out in a mass to any email address it can find on the internet. There will be a few things happening when you click the link. Ok so phishing is basically like you can see ... a fake email to get your information, but there are some ways to notice phishing, such as the when it addresses you at "Dear" they use an ambiguous title for you like "Youtuber" instead of your name since they don't know it. Also notice the way in which it has been written, sometime s the email can be strangely informal. But ultimately all phishing want you to give your information; either by fake website or just sending an email, WATCHOUT for suspicious reasons, and if they say there's a problem check it out first; sometimes they say they have technical problems and have lost your info, seems legit right? wrong, if this happened they would include it on their website to get to all users and not just email you (how could they if they lost your info after all).

Phishing doesn't just occur on email but fake websites too, to be 100% sure of the website you're using check for a padlock sign in the address bar next to the websites address to the left (you'll see this on google.com). It's kinda like a certificate of security. But even if your email has this it makes no difference to the security of the emails being sent to you, it just means the website itself won't phish you, it says nothing of other users of the website.

It's hard to say what exactly they do with the information, but it could be pretty bad. Username and password reuse is a common problem, so they could take the information and try to use it on other sites (like PayPal or Amazon or banks) and see if it works. Depending on how other sites work, they could also hijack those accounts by finding info in your e-mails and doing a password reset if the site does password resets by sending an e-mail to your account.

Also, this is why browsers should still show the actual address at the bottom of the page when you hover over a link. It makes spotting this kind of thing much easier.

What are they doing? Probably nothing with your youtube account information. It's easy to mess with someone's youtube account, but it's much harder to actually profit from it, since most youtube accounts aren't monetized, and don't have anything of value.

My experience with World of Warcraft definitely showed me what usually happens with these attacks. The passwords are sold in bulk to people who actually want to use them. THOSE people tend to use these passwords to break into other accounts, because people tend to use their email password for everything.

In world of warcraft, these passwords were used to hack into people's accounts so that those accounts could be stripped of all their belongings and maybe even used to farm gold with bots. Everything would be transferred to another compromised account, which would then sell the gold to other players. If any of these accounts were caught by Blizzard security, they would be shut down, but because there were a multitude of such accounts, a few account closures wouldn't hurt anything.

In this case, I don't know what the purpose is. Compromised accounts could be used to spread spam. They could also give access to other accounts like facebook. Someone's facebook account could then be used by a program to generate clicks that are paid for by other users of facebook who need likes or views... or by advertisers who want money from facebook which they get through clicks.

Even scarier is the possibility that someone's paypal and bank accounts could be compromised. This is less likely since it carries much steeper penalties and can even involve investigation by government agencies. However, the possibility does exist.

Bottom line: every account you care about needs to have a different password. If it's just a forum, it can be ok, but not your email and NOT your financial accounts. For the love of all things good DON'T use the same password for everything.

Hey minutephysics. So typically what users gain access to is your email address and password. If you're in the habit of using different passwords for websites you visit, you've probably just given away your contact list for more people to spam and phish using your account.

These scams are very easy to identify.  Even without looking at the link, this one should go in the trash.  Anything 'account verification' -> generally delete, unless you were expecting it.  "Dear Customer" -> delete.  "Dear [some company] Account Holder" -> delete.  "Dear [some company] User" -> delete.  "Dear [email username]" -> delete.  "Dear [email address]" -> delete.  Legitimate emails will address you with the name the company has one file.  Ideally this will be distinct from your email address.  And this most certainly does not apply only to youtube!  Junk like this from Facebook, Paypal, eBay, Bank of America, Chase, Wachovia, etc. is very common.  I have also gotten fake Facebook message notifications that try to do the same thing.  Basically, think before you click!

Couple of things you can keep an eye out for to know if you are dealing with a real email from a company or not. 1) If it says "Dear Customer" then it's most likely not real. Most companies these days will use the name you gave them when you created their account (not your user name, but your private "real" name. 2) If it says verify account information, and it's any email other than the one sent right after you create the account. Seriously, even if everything about it looks real (and let's say it is) go about your business as normal. If that email is real, then the company should have some important message for you when you log into your account the normal way instead of through some link in an email.

What these attack sites do or who's behind them?
1.  These attack sites allow the owner to log the ip's of anyone who visits their sites, sometimes can exploit webpages via SQL injections, and can even passively download malicious software onto your computer.  The username + login forms in these sites also log the input text which allows them to steal your information.
2. Anyone will a small amount of computer knowledge can develop a phishing site which logs passwords.  IP hacking and everything else I mentioned is for more advanced users.  Sometimes people do it for fun, some people do it to exploit one or a few users, and some steal thousands of usernames and passwords and sell them. 

And lastly, Google and other large companies always encourage users to only input sensitive information in webpages that have trusted certificates.  They also sometimes suggest they will only message you via youtube message rather than email.  They cant protect every idiot who doesn't follow simple guidelines.

This is phishing 101. ALWAYS check on which website you're entering your information.

These websites are generally hosted on hacked servers, so it's nearly impossible to figure out who is behind it. You can send an abuse message to the owner of the website, the company that hosts it and/or the owner of the IP. But even better is to inform the company that's being faked (in this case YouTube/Google, but banks are also very common). Most companies that deal with sensitive login information quickly respond and know how to deal with contacting abuse departments.

The goal is obviously to get your login information and then use this for malicious things, often by first selling it to whomever pays the most.

If you feel you MUST use a web browser for going into your email (which in itself I find a silly idea), then look out for the link panel at the bottom of the browser when you hover over the click. In a proper mail client (such as Thunderbird) you will see the linked URL in the status bar.

Another tell tale sign is that most phishing emails usually do not address you by your name but are anonymous, so they start with "Dear Youtube User" or the likes. That way it is easier to send them out to a big number of people.

Remember mail =/= gmail, there are other mail providers out there apart from "big brother" google, and it is always good to have multiple mail accounts  so you can keep your important private or business mail unpolluted. Again a proper email client (e.g. Thunderbird) will support multiple email accounts at the same time!

What the attack is doing is taking your email address and password to store in a database. Since most people use the same email address and password for every site they go to, this means the phishers now have access to many of your sites. Also, since they have access to your email, they can change your account info to lock you out of your own account as well. The motives the phishers have behind doing this can vary, but it puts you at risk of losing money, being used as a proxy to trick your friends and family into a similar phishing attack, and many more things that can in no way be good for you.

TL;DR: Phishers having your password is never good.

When you login to google, what you do is sending a packet of information to google saying hey, my information is this, can I have acces now? Google checks if it's valid and then if it is gives you acces.

There's really nothing more to it than this: they populate lists of youtube accounts with these sites, perform login checks, organizes the phished accounts into databases, and sell the databases to people who are interested in buying accounts that have subscriptions, views, popularity, etc.

Also: Google allows for 2-Step-Verification. If you have a smartphone, get the Google Authenticator, connect it with your Google Account. When you log in, Google will ask for a number, this number is generated by your authenticator and is only valid for a short time. It's an additional step while logging in, but people who are not in the possession of your phone won't be able to log in, because they don't have the authenticator and therefor can not know the correct number.

You should still be careful not to enter your password on phishing sites like this, but it's an added layer of security.

HEADS UP MINUTEPHYSICS:
Pause the vid at 1:10. Look at the set of numbers in bold in the address bar. That's an I.P address. If you copy-paste that into an I.P locator, or just send it to YouTube, you/they can pinpoint the geographic location of the pisher and take it from there. Hope this helps!

That's why I love reading email in a separate email client instead of any web mail software like gmail - I usually do not turn on HTML display, but read my messages in plain text only - so I definitely see more. If you use a web mail program, you'd need to have your browser set up so that it shows you the link address in (what formerly was) the browser status bar, although I don't know if that useful feature hasn't also been removed yet.
So, basically, the software gets more and more dumbed down for people not having to think while using it, and thus people lose more and more intrinsically valuable knowledge about the technology, while the attacks get more and more malicious.
Now, who is the guilty part? Software developers with a poor grasp of "usability" or "user friendliness", or naive users who don't think they have to think while using the technolgy, or evil attackers who try to scam gullible people into giving away something and thus causing harm for themselves?
Well, the evil forces have always been there, nobody liked them, and in the old world, at least in the more civilized places, there is some sort of police force that tries to contain the damage, but that doesn't work in the digital age any more.

In conclusion I opt for people having to know at least some basics and to be able to think while usind the technology in order to prevent themselves from harm.

More than just YouTube, Mr. Reich...any link in email should be vetted that way, making sure the actual target goes where you expect.  That is a very, very common trick of theirs, citing a URI in the visible text which goes where you expect, but having the actual link go somewhere totally different.  And that's exactly how to protect yourself against the vast majority of these, copy the link to your clipboard and paste it into a text editor for closer examination.  You know you're "in deep doodoo" when what eventually ends up in your address bar is a raw IP address, as you demonstrated.  Especially nasty are the deceptions which use encoded characters which look similar to the ones we expect, called an "IDN homograph attack."  (Look on Wikipedia for a full explanation.)
